awd_titl_txt: CT-ISG:   User-Aided Secure Association of Wireless Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
The popularity of personal gadgets opens up many new services for ordinary users. Many everyday usage scenarios involve two or more devices "working together". (Emerging scenarios are beginning to involve sensors and personal RFID tags.) Before working together, devices must be securely "paired" to enable secure and private communication. 

However, the human-imperceptible nature of wireless communication prompts the very real threat of Man-in-the-Middle (MiTM) attacks. Another challenge arises due to the lack of a global security infrastructure. Consequently, traditional cryptographic means alone are unsuitable, since unfamiliar devices have no prior security context and no common point of trust. Therefore, some human involvement in secure device pairing is unavoidable. At the same time, most devices have limited hardware and/or user interfaces, thus complicating human involvement. 

This project?s goals are three-fold: (1) design a set of pairing methods suitable for most common devices and a general user population, based on comprehensive and comparative usability studies, (2) develop secure pairing techniques for personal RFID tags, and (3) construct a set of user-friendly, scalable and secure methods for sensor initialization. 

Benefits of this project will include accumulation of valuable expertise in designing truly usable security methods. Notably, the project expects to experimentally assess the value of usable security with respect to the general population. Furthermore, the need for, and the utility of, user-centric secure control of personal RFID tags and sensors will be demonstrated. Since device pairing is one of the very few areas where security directly involves and affects the average user, the greatest impact of proposed research is expected to be the broader participation in security practices and better appreciation of security and its benefits. The project also emphasizes industry outreach and technology transfer by working with manufacturers and industrial consortia. 

In addition, students taking part in the project are expected to acquire currently uncommon skills at the cusp of Human-Computer Interaction, Usability and Cyber Trust.

por.por_cntn:
In the last 15 years, the security research community has become increasingly aware that usability is an important element of security. Thanks to advances in cryptographic research, efficient and secure tools and protocols are available for a variety of tasks. However, security software often depends on the average end-user for correct performance of critical tasks and decisions to function properly. Unsurprisingly, usability problems may result in severe vulnerabilities. As noted by the Computing Research Association in 2003:

"Giving end-users security controls they can understand and privacy they can control for the dynamic, pervasive computing environments of the future."

This was (and remains) one of the four grand challenges in Computer Science. This project contributed to addressing this challenge by making several significant contributions to usable security.

First, the project explored the design space for usable and secure device pairing methods, i.e., ways to establish a secure communication channel between two devices with no prior affiliation history. A ready example is the case of Bluetooth pairing, such as: a smartphone with an earpiece, or a  smartphone with a car phone setup. We focused on techniques that operate with primitive devices that lack certain usual user interface features (such as keypad and/or display). We developed three techniques: LOUD-and-CLEAR, HAPADEP and BEDA.

Second, the project investigated comparative usability and security of numerous proposed secure device association techniques. We conducted extensive user studies (that included observation and questionnaires)
to assess each technique. Our results were appreciated no only by the research community but also by  device manufacturers, e.g., Nokia.

We followed up on this work by considering a number of techniques for establishing an ad hoc secure channel for a group of devices. This setting is exemplified by a spontaneous conference where several people (each with a personal device) need to set up a secure electronic meeting. We thoroughly evaluated several available techniques and compared their usability and security features.

Third, witnessing the emergence, and anticipating increased popularity, of NFC (or RFID) tags in e-documents (e.g., passports and driver's licenses) and payment instruments (e.g., credit cards), we considered the heretofore unsolved problem of how a clock-less tag can check timely revocation
of a public key certificate presented by an tag reader. After proposing a technique that involved passive displays and minimal user participation, we proposed a method for mitigating so-called "amount fraud" whereby a merchant charges a card-paying customer a different amount from what
the latter expects; it also involves user participation and passive on-card displays. We then conducted a usability study to evaluate user acceptability. Results showed that users are both ready and able to perform simple tasks with low error rates.
